item.title: ‘Their Country Is Being Invaded’: Exodus of Venezuelans Overwhelms Northern Brazil
item.media:description: Venezuelans cross the border into Brazil.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: As thousands of Venezuelans flee their homeland each day, the region’s tolerance for immigrants is being tested.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: The Interpreter: How Trump’s Mixed Signals Complicate America’s Role in the World
item.media:description: President Trump has taken divergent approaches to North Korea and Iran over nuclear weapons.
item.description: President Trump’s inconsistent responses to Iran and North Korea risk conveying a very different message to the world than the one he may wish to send.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Korean Accord Draws Praise, and Caution, From North’s Neighbors
item.media:description: Watching a live broadcast in Seoul, South Korea, of the inter-Korean summit meeting on Friday.
item.description: China, Japan and Russia, which were not part of the summit meeting, acknowledged that most of the hard work still lay ahead.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: North Korean News Outlets Fawn Over Kim but Offer Few Clues on Nuclear Plan
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, left, and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, near the end of their summit meeting Friday at the truce village of Panmunjom.
item.description: After the inter-Korean summit meeting, the crucial question remains: Is Kim Jong-un willing to abandon his atomic weapons?
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Irish Voters Speak Out on Landmark Abortion Referendum
item.media:description: A demonstration in favor of more liberal abortion laws, in Dublin in March.
item.description: The Times asked readers in Ireland to give their opinion about the country’s coming vote on lifting the constitutional ban on abortion.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alfie Evans, Terminally Ill British Toddler at Center of Court Fight, Dies
item.media:description: Balloons and toys in support of the toddler Alfie Evans, outside the Alder Hey Children’s Hospital in Liverpool, England.
item.description: The 23-month-old had a rare degenerative brain condition. His parents fought to continue treatment, but his doctors said further medical care would have been futile.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: ‘We Are Nicaragua’: Students Revolt, but Now Face a More Daunting Task
item.media:description: Young people carrying makeshift weapons outside Nicaragua’s Polytechnic University on Wednesday.
item.description: University students and young professionals have pulled off a feat few in Nicaragua thought possible: Their protests have loosened President Daniel Ortega’s grip on power.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Plan to Storm Fence Gets Bloody Preview in Gaza
item.media:description: A wounded protester was evacuated on Friday near Khan Younis, Gaza.
item.description: After hundreds of Palestinian protesters attacked the fence between Israel and Gaza, Israeli troops opened fire, killing four and wounding hundreds.
item.dc:creator: IYAD ABUHEWEILA and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Mike Pompeo, Wasting No Time, Warns Europe About Iran Deal
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, center, with Jens Stoltenberg, the NATO secretary general, in Brussels on Friday. “I was sworn in yesterday afternoon, I hopped straight on a plane and came straight here,” Mr. Pompeo said.
item.description: A day after being sworn in, the top American diplomat told leaders of the NATO alliance in Brussels that President Trump might soon scrap the Iran nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Eight of 10 Victims in Toronto Van Rampage Were Women
item.media:description: One of several memorials on Yonge Street in Toronto to the victims hit by a van driver this week.
item.description: The police would not say whether the van’s driver had targeted women, but they are examining a Facebook message that was hostile to them.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: He Wanted to Escape His Childhood. Now, It Fuels His Art.
item.media:description: Xavier Dolan in his apartment in Montreal. At 29, he has already directed seven films.
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.description: As the Canadian director Xavier Dolan prepares for the release of his first English-language film, he reflects on his early success, having a “big mouth” and unrequited love.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: The Death and Life of John F. Donovan (Movie)

item.title: A Spy’s Tale: The TV Prankster Who Says He Became a Double Agent
item.media:description: Robert Moore represented himself as a documentary filmmaker to spy on anti-asbestos activists for K2 Intelligence, an investigative firm. Now facing a lawsuit, he contends that he soon switched sides and secretly worked to help the activists.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Robert Moore posed as a documentary filmmaker to monitor activists for a K2 Intelligence client. He contends he switched sides. Now he’s being sued. His unusual case offers a peek into a growing industry.
item.dc:creator: BARRY MEIER

item.title: Kenya Bans Film About 2 Girls in Love Because It’s ‘Too Hopeful’
item.media:description: Wanuri Kahiu, the director of the film “Rafiki,” in Nairobi, Kenya, on Friday. The movie, which depicts a love story between two young women has been banned in Kenya.
item.description: The first Kenyan entry ever nominated for an award at the Cannes Film Festival is banned at home because the film board said it “legitimizes homosexuality.”
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: A Libyan Strongman Returns Home and Asserts That He’s Fit
item.media:description: Gen. Khalifa Hifter, center, was welcomed back to Benghazi, Libya, this week. He offered no specifics about the health problems that had caused him to seek treatment in France.
item.media:credit: Libyan National Army, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Gen. Khalifa Hifter returned to his Benghazi stronghold on Thursday after weeks in a Paris hospital, and he dismissed reports he was seriously ill.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Here Are the Biggest Stories in American Politics This Week
item.media:description: President Trump delivering a toast on Tuesday during the state dinner for President Emmanuel Macron of France.
item.description: Whether it was the withdrawal of the president’s nominee to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs or a summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea, it was a big week in American politics and diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: EMILY COCHRANE

item.title: From Dictator to Diplomat: Kim Jong-un’s Extreme Makeover
item.description: How did North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, go from being an international pariah to a smiling diplomat in a matter of a few months?

item.title: North Korea, Angela Merkel, Golden State Killer: Your Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: News Analysis: Koreans Set the Table for a Deal That Trump Will Try to Close
item.media:description: People in Seoul, South Korea, watched live coverage on Friday of a meeting between President Moon Jae-in and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un.
item.description: North and South Korea agreed to seek denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but President Trump and North Korea’s leader now have many details to iron out.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: What Kim Jong-un’s Day In South Korea Looked Like
item.description: A handshake and smiles, the rare sound of the North Korean leader’s voice on camera and running bodyguards were among the spectacles in the historic meeting between the two Korean leaders.

item.title: Times Journalists on Covering the Toronto Attack: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Hours after Monday’s rampage by a van driver that killed 10 people in Toronto, people gathered at a memorial across Yonge Street from the first deaths.
item.description: A flurry of motion by Times editors and reporters followed the rampage. Members of the team now take a moment to reflect.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: President Trump Is Coming to Britain. Here’s What He Can Expect.
item.media:description: President Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle Obama, with Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip in London on a state visit to Britain in 2011.
item.description: Mr. Trump is invited to visit Britain and is likely attending. Here are some early signals on his visit.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Knife Attack at Chinese Middle School Leaves Nine Children Dead
item.description: The episode, one of the worst stabbings in recent years, revived fears about school safety, a perennial concern.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and IRIS ZHAO

item.title: Republicans on House Intelligence Panel Absolve Trump Campaign in Russian Meddling
item.media:description: A polling place in the Bronx in November 2016. The House Intelligence Committee report on Russian election interference includes a range of recommendations for protecting ballots.
item.description: The committee’s investigation devolved into partisan bickering as Democrats accused the Republicans leading the panel of ignoring crucial evidence and obvious leads.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS and SHARON LaFRANIERE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Lawyer Who Was Said to Have Dirt on Clinton Had Closer Ties to Kremlin Than She Let On
item.media:description: Natalia V. Veselnitskaya had long insisted that she met top Trump campaign officials in 2016 in a private capacity. Newly disclosed details undermine her assertion.
item.description: Newly released emails have renewed questions about who the lawyer, Natalia V. Veselnitskaya, was representing when she met with top Trump campaign officials promising dirt on Hillary Clinton.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and SHARON LaFRANIERE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: North and South Korean Leaders’ Own Words in Meeting at the DMZ
item.media:description: A screen in Goyang, South Korea, showing live video of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, and South Korea’s president, Moon Jae-in, during their summit meeting on Friday.
item.description: The talks offered a rare peek at the unscripted speech of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, without the filter of his state news media.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: No, Your Dog Can’t Get Autism From a Vaccine
item.media:description: A British morning television show asked to hear from viewers who had declined vaccinations for their dogs out of fear of side effects.
item.description: British officials were spurred to rebut claims about the possible side effects of vaccines because the “anti-vaxxer” movement blamed for measles outbreaks in the U.S. and Europe has turned to pets.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: ITV (British television network - was offered iTV, which is either a case error in the tag name or another network...)

item.title: Louis Arthur Charles: The British Royal Baby’s Name Is Revealed
item.media:description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge outside the Lindo Wing of St. Mary’s Hospital in London on Monday with their third child.
item.description: Prince Louis, the third child of Prince William and his wife, Catherine, is the fifth in line to the British throne.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: North and South Korea Set Bold Goals: A Final Peace and No Nuclear Arms
item.media:description: Mr. Moon and Mr. Kim walking the red carpet at a welcoming ceremony outside the Peace House in the village of Panmunjom.
item.description: Kim Jong-un of North Korea and Moon Jae-in of the South agreed to work to formally end the Korean War and rid the peninsula of nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: North and South Korea Summit Is Short on Details, but Long on Theater
item.description: It was the stagecraft of Friday’s meeting that offered hope, when statecraft delivered only vague pledges to work toward a peace treaty.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Kim Jong-un Crosses Inter-Korean Border
item.description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, walked across the inter-Korean border to meet the South’s president, Moon Jae-in. No North Korean leader had made the journey in the two countries’ 70-year history of bitter rivalry.

item.title: Supporters of El Salvador’s Abortion Ban Foil Efforts to Soften It
item.media:description: Demonstrators participated in a march against abortion in San Salvador earlier this month.
item.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
item.description: Lawmakers adjourned without voting on exceptions to the country’s total ban on abortion, including cases in which the life of the woman is at risk.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Trump’s On-Again, Off-Again Trip to Britain Is Set for July
item.media:description: President Trump with British Prime Minister Theresa May during her visit to the White House in January 2017, when she invited him to Britain. He accepted, but since then the visit has been repeatedly delayed.
item.description: The White House has repeatedly put off the trip amid friction between the American president and one of the United States’ closest allies.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Bill Cosby, Michael Cohen, Golden State Killer: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Parents Sue North Korea Over College Student’s Death After Time in Prison
item.media:description: Fred and Cindy Warmbier, the parents of Otto F. Warmbier, allege in a lawsuit that North Korea “took Otto hostage for its own wrongful ends and brutally tortured and murdered him.”
item.description: Otto F. Warmbier, a student at the University of Virginia, died after suffering a severe brain injury during 17 months in custody in Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: After Arduous Journey, Migrants See Stubborn Obstacle: Trump
item.media:description: Migrants from Central America walked to a shelter in Tijuana this week.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of Central American migrants are in Tijuana, where most plan to seek asylum in the United States, after traveling through Mexico.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Korea Talks Begin as Kim Jong-un Crosses to South’s Side of DMZ
item.media:description: Mr. Kim and Mr. Moon at the welcoming ceremony.
item.description: A meeting between Mr. Kim, North Korea’s leader, and President Moon Jae-in of South Korea seemed unthinkable just a few months ago.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: For Catalans, a Day of Books, Roses and, of Course, Politics
item.media:description: People crowded along historic Las Ramblas promenade of Barcelona, Spain, to buy books and roses at makeshift stands as Catalans celebrated the day of their patron.
item.description: Catalans have come together on the feast of Sant Jordi for centuries. This year, after months of secessionist turmoil, political division was perhaps inevitable.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Facebook Faces Tough Questions in Britain That It Avoided in the U.S.
item.description: Facebook’s chief technology officer testified before a British panel in a hearing that stood in stark contrast to the efforts of American lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Fight Over Alfie Evans, a Brain-Damaged Baby, Divides U.K.
item.media:description: Tom Evans, the father of Alfie Evans, speaking to the news media outside Alder Hey Children’s Hospital in Liverpool, Britain, on Thursday.
item.description: Courts have barred the parents of the baby from seeking more medical care, calling it contrary to his interests. The Vatican, Poland and Italy have weighed in.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Verdict in Pamplona Gang Rape Case Sets Off Immediate Outcry
item.media:description: A protest Thursday against the verdict in the trial of five men accused of gang raping an 18-year-old in Pamplona. The court found the men guilty of “sexual abuse,” but cleared them of the more serious charge of rape.
item.description: A Spanish court sentenced five men for sexually abusing a woman during the bull-running festival, but cleared them of rape in a case seen as a bellwether of women’s rights.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Flash Flood Kills at Least 9 Israeli Teenagers on ‘Bonding’ Hike
item.media:description: A search mission gathered Thursday to seek young hikers near Arava in southern Israel after flash floods swept through the area. At least nine hikers were killed.
item.description: The youths were taking part in a 10-month program for high school graduates before heading into the military.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Senate Confirms C.I.A. Chief Mike Pompeo to Be Secretary of State
item.media:description: Mike Pompeo’s year of service as the director of the C.I.A. has given him a running start as he becomes Secretary of State.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: After the Senate voted to confirm Mike Pompeo to be the nation’s 70th secretary of state, he turned to urgent problems around the world.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and THOMAS KAPLAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Pakistani Court Bans Lawmaker in Latest Blow to Governing Party
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Khawaja Muhammad Asif of Pakistan in Beijing on Tuesday.
item.description: The banning of the foreign minister followed other inquiries brought against figures of his party, and comes ahead of national elections in July.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Tas-Yuryakh Journal: From Siberia, an Unlikely Cry: ‘We Need Greenpeace Out Here!’
item.media:description: Every spring, thousands of miles of so-called winter highways, mostly serving oil and mining towns in Siberia and in the far north of European Russia, melt back into the swamps from which they were conjured up the previous fall.
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.description: Siberian truck drivers, who haul heavy loads on winter roads made of ice that melts earlier every year, are true believers in climate change.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: 10 South Sudan Aid Workers Are Abducted, U.N. Says
item.description: The humanitarian workers were traveling in a convoy between two cities when they disappeared.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Angela Merkel Is Next to Visit Trump, Skipping the Bonhomie
item.media:description: President Trump and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in the Oval Office last year, during a visit in which Mr. Trump missed or ignored a cue to shake hands with Ms. Merkel. Few expect a warmer rapport this time.
item.description: In contrast to the pomp lavished on the French president, the German chancellor will be given a working lunch and is expected to be all business.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Bus Driver in India Is Distracted by Music, and 13 Children Die
item.description: For the third time in recent years, a negligent school bus driver in the country who was listening to music crashed into a train.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Walmart, With Billions to Spend, Seeks Flipkart E-Commerce Site in India
item.media:description: Kalyan Krishnamurthy, Flipkart’s chief executive, is credited with turning the online retailer around after a rocky start.
item.description: The company is said to be in talks to acquire Flipkart, India’s leading online retailer, to counter Amazon’s push into the country.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL, MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and MICHAEL CORKERY
